Award.AwardTitle: The Low Surface Brightness Sky with the 48-Lens Dragonfly Telephoto Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use their array of telephoto lenses, Dragonfly, to observe the dim starlight from galaxies. Such dim optical signals have never been observed before. The innovative array is located in New Mexico and operated from Connecticut or Ontario, Canada. The observations will be used to test models and simulations of the dim starlight. The team will continue to develop industrial links with Canon, a lens manufacturer. Undergraduates and graduate students will gain hands-on experience with instrumentation, software and observations.

The team will use their purpose-built array to observe the low-surface-brightness stellar emission from galaxies. Their goals are to study (1) the outskirts of nearby galaxies, (2) the faint dwarf galaxies around luminous spiral galaxies, and (3) the ultra diffuse galaxies in the Coma Cluster and Virgo Cluster.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have undertaken a survey of the sky using a novel telescope concept, the Dragonfly Telephoto Array. Dragonfly is comprised of 48 high-end telephoto lenses that all look at the same piece of sky simultaneously. These lenses are ideally suited for finding things in the sky that are both large and faint, and they can detect things that are missed by even the largest conventional telescopes on the ground and in space.

In a previous NSF-supported project we used a prototype of the array, consisting of 10 lenses, to look at a number of relatively nearby, large galaxies. Since then we upgraded the array to 48 lenses, and in this program we surveyed regions of the sky with this much bigger array.

We are still analyzing our findings; the data are so rich that it is not possible to analyze and publish everything that is in them during the lifetime of the grant. Among our results are the discovery of many faint structures around nearby galaxies and a measurement of the total light in galaxies - something that is surprisingly difficult to do. Ironically, one of our most surprising results is the discovery that a previously-claimed spectacular loop around a galaxy does not exist - illustrating the difficult of this kind of work.

Once all the survey data are properly curated we will make them publicly available, so that anyone in the world can access them and do interesting science. The attached image shows the team with one of the two mounts of the Dragonfly Telephoto Array (a second mount is in an identical dome about 50 feet away). More information can be found on our website, www.dragonflytelescope.org
